#!/bin/bash
# Aggregates user prompts into a project-level PROMPTS.md file

set -uo pipefail

# Only process UserPromptSubmit events
EVENT_TYPE="${1:-unknown}"
if [ "$EVENT_TYPE" != "UserPromptSubmit" ]; then
  exit 0
fi

# Use project directory if available
if [ -z "${CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR:-}" ]; then
  # No project directory, skip
  exit 0
fi

# Validate project directory - no path traversal
if [[ "$CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR" == *".."* ]]; then
  echo "Error: Invalid project directory path" >&2
  exit 0
fi

PROMPTS_FILE="$CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR/PROMPTS.md"

# Read input from stdin
input=$(cat)

# If input is empty, exit
if [ -z "$input" ]; then
  exit 0
fi

# Extract the prompt text from the JSON input
# The UserPromptSubmit event should contain the prompt text
prompt_text=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.prompt // empty')

# If no prompt text found, exit
if [ -z "$prompt_text" ]; then
  exit 0
fi

# Create or append to PROMPTS.md
if [ -f "$PROMPTS_FILE" ]; then
  # File exists, append with separator
  echo -e "\n\n---\n" >> "$PROMPTS_FILE"
  echo "$prompt_text" >> "$PROMPTS_FILE"
else
  # New file, just write the prompt
  echo "$prompt_text" > "$PROMPTS_FILE"
fi

# Don't block any operations
exit 0

  echo "$prompt_text" > "$PROMPTS_FILE"
fi

# Don't block any operations
exit 0

file.content:
Replicates v2 Python SDK is now in public beta. 

This new version is a complete rewrite of the SDK, built in partnership with [Stainless](https://www.stainless.com/customers/replicate), the company that helps design and maintain official SDKs for companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, and Cloudflare.

Heres whats covered in this doc:

- [What's new?](#17) - a high-level `.use()` method and 1:1 mappings to every HTTP API operation.
- [Why rewrite?](#61) - details about how and why we're making the jump to v2.0
- [API design](#29) - high-level abstractions all the way down to low-level plumbing.
- [New SDK features](#41) - Type hints, pagination, streaming, customer loggers, etc.
- [Installation](#68) - how to get the new beta SDK
- [Usage](#73) - how to use the new v2 SDK in your Python apps
- [Migrating from v1 to v2](#83) - an agent-friendly guide to all the changes
- [Pinning to v1](#93) - how to stick to the old client

## Whats new?

Running AI models should be as easy as installing and running a package from PyPI.

We designed a new **`replicate.use()`** method for the Python SDK with this idea in mind.

It lets you run models as Python functions:

```python
# pip install --pre replicate

import replicate

claude = replicate.use("anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet")
seedream = replicate.use("bytedance/seedream-4")
veo = replicate.use("google/veo-3-fast")

# Enhance a simple prompt
image_prompt = claude(prompt="bananas wearing cowboy hats", system_prompt="turn prompts into image prompts")

# Generate an image from the enhanced prompt
images = seedream(prompt=image_prompt)

# Generate a video from the image
video = veo(prompt="dancing bananas", image_input=images[0])

open(video)
```

The new `.use()` method also supports streaming output. Heres an example showing how to consume output tokens from Claude Sonnet 4.5 while the model is running:

```python
import replicate

claude = replicate.use("anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet", streaming=True)

for chunk in claude(prompt="Write a haiku about streaming output."):
    print(str(chunk), end="")
    
# Bytes flow through the pipe
# Data chunks arrive in waves
# Code drinks from the stream
```

---

## API design

Our new SDK was designed to be approachable for newcomers while also being feature-complete for power users. There are three levels of APIs built into the new SDK, varying from simple high-level abstractions to powerful low-level methods that you give you complete control:

### High-level API

The v2 SDK provides a new `replicate.use()` method that make it easy to run models and get their output all at once or as a streaming response. The `replicate.run()` method is still supported so your applications will continue to work, but recommend using `use()` going forward.

### Mid-level API

The v2 SDK has methods for every single operation available in our [public HTTP API](https://replicate.com/api), like `search()`, `predictions.create()` , and `collections.list().` These more fine-grained methods are defined by our [OpenAPI schema](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/openapi), and updated in lock-step with our API. Every new feature, bug fix, or documentation improvement in our API becomes available immediately in a new release of the Python SDK. See our [HTTP API docs](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http) and [Python SDK docs](https://sdks.replicate.com/python/) for reference.

The SDK now supports all of these API operations:

- [`search`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#search)-Search models, collections, and docs (beta)
- [`predictions.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.create)-Create a prediction
- [`predictions.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.get)-Get a prediction
- [`predictions.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.list)-List predictions
- [`predictions.cancel`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.cancel)-Cancel a prediction
- [`models.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.create)-Create a model
- [`models.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.get)-Get a model
- [`models.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.list)-List public models
- [`models.update`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.update)-Update metadata for a model
- [`models.search`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.search)-Search public models
- [`models.delete`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.delete)-Delete a model
- [`models.examples.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.examples.list)-List examples for a model
- [`models.predictions.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.predictions.create)-Create a prediction using an official model
- [`models.readme.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.readme.get)-Get a model's README
- [`models.versions.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.versions.get)-Get a model version
- [`models.versions.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.versions.list)-List model versions
- [`models.versions.delete`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.versions.delete)-Delete a model version
- [`collections.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#collections.get)-Get a collection of models
- [`collections.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#collections.list)-List collections of models
- [`deployments.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.create)-Create a deployment
- [`deployments.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.get)-Get a deployment
- [`deployments.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.list)-List deployments
- [`deployments.update`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.update)-Update a deployment
- [`deployments.delete`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.delete)-Delete a deployment
- [`deployments.predictions.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.predictions.create)-Create a prediction using a deployment
- [`trainings.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#trainings.create)-Create a training
- [`trainings.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#trainings.get)-Get a training
- [`trainings.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#trainings.list)-List trainings
- [`trainings.cancel`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#trainings.cancel)-Cancel a training
- [`hardware.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#hardware.list)-List available hardware for models
- [`account.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#account.get)-Get the authenticated account
- [`webhooks.default.secret.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#webhooks.default.secret.get)-Get the signing secret for the default webhook

### Low-level API

The v2 SDK includes generic request methods like `replicate.get()` and `replicate.post()` for making custom API requests with full control over the request and response. This is useful for testing undocumented APIs, setting custom headers, or getting lower-level access to response objects.

---

## New SDK features

In addition to the new API design, there are loads of new features in the v2 SDK:

- [**Type hints**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#using-types): Typed requests and responses provide autocomplete and documentation within your editor.
- [**Pagination**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#pagination): All list methods are paginated, and the SDK provides auto-paginating iterators with each list response so you do not have to request successive pages manually.
- [**Retries**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#retries): Certain errors like 408, 409, 429, and >=500 are automatically retried 2 times by default, with a short exponential backoff.
- [**Async/await support**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#async-usage): Full async client with `AsyncReplicate` that supports all SDK methods including `run()` and `stream()`.
- [**Alternative HTTP backends**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#with-aiohttp): Optional aiohttp support for improved concurrency performance in async applications.
- [**Streaming output**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#run-a-model-and-stream-its-output): Stream model outputs in real-time with `replicate.stream()` for language models.
- [**File upload flexibility**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#file-uploads): Pass files as URLs, file handles, bytes, PathLike objects, or tuples of `(filename, contents, media_type)`.
- [**Raw response access**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#accessing-raw-response-data-eg-headers): Access response headers and raw data with `.with_raw_response` and `.with_streaming_response`.
- [**Per-request configuration**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#retries): Override client options on a per-request basis with `.with_options()`.
- [**Configurable timeouts**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#timeouts): Fine-grained timeout control at the client or request level, including separate read/write/connect timeouts.
- [**Better error handling**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#handling-errors): Specific exception types for different HTTP status codes (`BadRequestError`, `AuthenticationError`, `RateLimitError`, etc.) with access to underlying response data.
- [**Manual pagination control**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#pagination): Granular page control with `has_next_page()`, `next_page_info()`, and `get_next_page()` methods.
- [**Response serialization**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#using-types): Pydantic models with built-in `.to_json()` and `.to_dict()` methods.
- [**Logging support**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#logging): Built-in logging via `REPLICATE_LOG` environment variable.
- [**Context manager support**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#managing-http-resources): Proper resource management with context managers for both sync and async clients.

For more details about all these new features, see the [README](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta).

## Why rewrite?

The v2 Python SDK is generated dynamically from our public [OpenAPI schema](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/openapi). This allows us to automate client code generation and provide a Python API with method names, type hints, and documentation that is perfectly consistent with our HTTP API.

Now that most of the client code is generated dynamically, all changes to Replicates HTTP API are automatically supported by the Python SDK. This means whenever we add a new operation (like the [new search API](https://replicate.com/blog/new-search-api)) or improve our docs for an existing API (like [predictions.create()](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.create)), the changes are automatically published in a new release of the Python SDK.

## Installation

To get started using the public beta pre-release, pip install it with the `--pre` flag:

```bash
pip install --pre replicate
```

## Usage

For basic usage, the new 2.x client works just like the old 1.x client.

As always, you can import the library and run models with just a few lines of code:

```bash
import replicate

model = "anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet"
prompt = "Write me a poem about SDKs"
output = replicate.run(model, input={"prompt": prompt})
print(output)
```

You can also stream output as the model is running:

```python
import replicate

claude = replicate.use("anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet", streaming=True)

for event in claude(prompt="Write a haiku about streaming output."):
    print(str(event), end="")
```

Want to try it out but dont have Python at your disposal? Check out the [Google Colab notebook](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1FGlnCY1-TdYoyNsFg83L2lwFoWS5F7Xe?usp=sharing).

See [sdks.replicate.com/python](https://sdks.replicate.com/python/) for a complete summary of available methods.

## Migrating from v1 to v2

v2 is a complete rewrite of the Python SDK, so there are user-facing **breaking changes** you should be aware of if youre migrating an existing codebase from v1 to v2. Weve published a guide to simplify the migration process:

[**https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md)

We recommend feeding this guide to an agent like Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, Gemini CLI, or Cursor to help you automate the process of migrating your project from v1 to v2.

## Pinning to v1

v2 has lots of new bells and whistles, but you are not required to upgrade. If youre already using the v1 version and want to continue using it, pin the version number in your dependency file.

See [pinning](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md#pinning-to-the-legacy-v1-sdk) in the migration guide for details.

- [**Raw response access**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#accessing-raw-response-data-eg-headers): Access response headers and raw data with `.with_raw_response` and `.with_streaming_response`.
- [**Per-request configuration**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#retries): Override client options on a per-request basis with `.with_options()`.
- [**Configurable timeouts**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#timeouts): Fine-grained timeout control at the client or request level, including separate read/write/connect timeouts.
- [**Better error handling**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#handling-errors): Specific exception types for different HTTP status codes (`BadRequestError`, `AuthenticationError`, `RateLimitError`, etc.) with access to underlying response data.
- [**Manual pagination control**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#pagination): Granular page control with `has_next_page()`, `next_page_info()`, and `get_next_page()` methods.
- [**Response serialization**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#using-types): Pydantic models with built-in `.to_json()` and `.to_dict()` methods.
- [**Logging support**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#logging): Built-in logging via `REPLICATE_LOG` environment variable.
- [**Context manager support**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#managing-http-resources): Proper resource management with context managers for both sync and async clients.

For more details about all these new features, see the [README](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta).

## Why rewrite?

The v2 Python SDK is generated dynamically from our public [OpenAPI schema](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/openapi). This allows us to automate client code generation and provide a Python API with method names, type hints, and documentation that is perfectly consistent with our HTTP API.

Now that most of the client code is generated dynamically, all changes to Replicates HTTP API are automatically supported by the Python SDK. This means whenever we add a new operation (like the [new search API](https://replicate.com/blog/new-search-api)) or improve our docs for an existing API (like [predictions.create()](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.create)), the changes are automatically published in a new release of the Python SDK.

## Installation

To get started using the public beta pre-release, pip install it with the `--pre` flag:

```bash
pip install --pre replicate
```

## Usage

For basic usage, the new 2.x client works just like the old 1.x client.

As always, you can import the library and run models with just a few lines of code:

```bash
import replicate

model = "anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet"
prompt = "Write me a poem about SDKs"
output = replicate.run(model, input={"prompt": prompt})
print(output)
```

You can also stream output as the model is running:

```python
import replicate

claude = replicate.use("anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet", streaming=True)

for event in claude(prompt="Write a haiku about streaming output."):
    print(str(event), end="")
```

Want to try it out but dont have Python at your disposal? Check out the [Google Colab notebook](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1FGlnCY1-TdYoyNsFg83L2lwFoWS5F7Xe?usp=sharing).

See [sdks.replicate.com/python](https://sdks.replicate.com/python/) for a complete summary of available methods.

## Migrating from v1 to v2

v2 is a complete rewrite of the Python SDK, so there are user-facing **breaking changes** you should be aware of if youre migrating an existing codebase from v1 to v2. Weve published a guide to simplify the migration process:

[**https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md)

We recommend feeding this guide to an agent like Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, Gemini CLI, or Cursor to help you automate the process of migrating your project from v1 to v2.

## Pinning to v1

v2 has lots of new bells and whistles, but you are not required to upgrade. If youre already using the v1 version and want to continue using it, pin the version number in your dependency file.

See [pinning](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md#pinning-to-the-legacy-v1-sdk) in the migration guide for details.

tool_response.originalFile:
Replicates v2 Python SDK is now in public beta. 

This new version is a complete rewrite of the SDK, built in partnership with [Stainless](https://www.stainless.com/customers/replicate), the company that helps design and maintain official SDKs for companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, and Cloudflare.

Heres whats covered in this doc:

- [What's new?](#whats-new) - a high-level `.use()` method and 1:1 mappings to every HTTP API operation.
- [Why rewrite?](#why-rewrite) - details about how and why we're making the jump to v2.0
- [API design](#api-design) - high-level abstractions all the way down to low-level plumbing.
- [New SDK features](#new-sdk-features) - Type hints, pagination, streaming, customer loggers, etc.
- [Installation](#installation) - how to get the new beta SDK
- [Usage](#usage) - how to use the new v2 SDK in your Python apps
- [Migrating from v1 to v2](#migrating-from-v1-to-v2) - an agent-friendly guide to all the changes
- [Pinning to v1](#pinning-to-v1) - how to stick to the old client

## Whats new?

Running AI models should be as easy as installing and running a package from PyPI.

We designed a new **`replicate.use()`** method for the Python SDK with this idea in mind.

It lets you run models as Python functions:

```python
# pip install --pre replicate

import replicate

claude = replicate.use("anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet")
seedream = replicate.use("bytedance/seedream-4")
veo = replicate.use("google/veo-3-fast")

# Enhance a simple prompt
image_prompt = claude(prompt="bananas wearing cowboy hats", system_prompt="turn prompts into image prompts")

# Generate an image from the enhanced prompt
images = seedream(prompt=image_prompt)

# Generate a video from the image
video = veo(prompt="dancing bananas", image_input=images[0])

open(video)
```

The new `.use()` method also supports streaming output. Heres an example showing how to consume output tokens from Claude Sonnet 4.5 while the model is running:

```python
import replicate

claude = replicate.use("anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet", streaming=True)

for chunk in claude(prompt="Write a haiku about streaming output."):
    print(str(chunk), end="")
    
# Bytes flow through the pipe
# Data chunks arrive in waves
# Code drinks from the stream
```

---

## API design

Our new SDK was designed to be approachable for newcomers while also being feature-complete for power users. There are three levels of APIs built into the new SDK, varying from simple high-level abstractions to powerful low-level methods that you give you complete control:

### High-level API

The v2 SDK provides a new `replicate.use()` method that make it easy to run models and get their output all at once or as a streaming response. The `replicate.run()` method is still supported so your applications will continue to work, but recommend using `use()` going forward.

### Mid-level API

The v2 SDK has methods for every single operation available in our [public HTTP API](https://replicate.com/api), like `search()`, `predictions.create()` , and `collections.list().` These more fine-grained methods are defined by our [OpenAPI schema](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/openapi), and updated in lock-step with our API. Every new feature, bug fix, or documentation improvement in our API becomes available immediately in a new release of the Python SDK. See our [HTTP API docs](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http) and [Python SDK docs](https://sdks.replicate.com/python/) for reference.

The SDK now supports all of these API operations:

- [`search`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#search)-Search models, collections, and docs (beta)
- [`predictions.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.create)-Create a prediction
- [`predictions.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.get)-Get a prediction
- [`predictions.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.list)-List predictions
- [`predictions.cancel`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.cancel)-Cancel a prediction
- [`models.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.create)-Create a model
- [`models.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.get)-Get a model
- [`models.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.list)-List public models
- [`models.update`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.update)-Update metadata for a model
- [`models.search`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.search)-Search public models
- [`models.delete`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.delete)-Delete a model
- [`models.examples.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.examples.list)-List examples for a model
- [`models.predictions.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.predictions.create)-Create a prediction using an official model
- [`models.readme.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.readme.get)-Get a model's README
- [`models.versions.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.versions.get)-Get a model version
- [`models.versions.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.versions.list)-List model versions
- [`models.versions.delete`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#models.versions.delete)-Delete a model version
- [`collections.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#collections.get)-Get a collection of models
- [`collections.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#collections.list)-List collections of models
- [`deployments.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.create)-Create a deployment
- [`deployments.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.get)-Get a deployment
- [`deployments.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.list)-List deployments
- [`deployments.update`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.update)-Update a deployment
- [`deployments.delete`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.delete)-Delete a deployment
- [`deployments.predictions.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#deployments.predictions.create)-Create a prediction using a deployment
- [`trainings.create`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#trainings.create)-Create a training
- [`trainings.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#trainings.get)-Get a training
- [`trainings.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#trainings.list)-List trainings
- [`trainings.cancel`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#trainings.cancel)-Cancel a training
- [`hardware.list`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#hardware.list)-List available hardware for models
- [`account.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#account.get)-Get the authenticated account
- [`webhooks.default.secret.get`](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#webhooks.default.secret.get)-Get the signing secret for the default webhook

### Low-level API

The v2 SDK includes generic request methods like `replicate.get()` and `replicate.post()` for making custom API requests with full control over the request and response. This is useful for testing undocumented APIs, setting custom headers, or getting lower-level access to response objects.

---

## New SDK features

In addition to the new API design, there are loads of new features in the v2 SDK:

- [**Type hints**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#using-types): Typed requests and responses provide autocomplete and documentation within your editor.
- [**Pagination**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#pagination): All list methods are paginated, and the SDK provides auto-paginating iterators with each list response so you do not have to request successive pages manually.
- [**Retries**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#retries): Certain errors like 408, 409, 429, and >=500 are automatically retried 2 times by default, with a short exponential backoff.
- [**Async/await support**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#async-usage): Full async client with `AsyncReplicate` that supports all SDK methods including `run()` and `stream()`.
- [**Alternative HTTP backends**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#with-aiohttp): Optional aiohttp support for improved concurrency performance in async applications.
- [**Streaming output**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#run-a-model-and-stream-its-output): Stream model outputs in real-time with `replicate.stream()` for language models.
- [**File upload flexibility**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#file-uploads): Pass files as URLs, file handles, bytes, PathLike objects, or tuples of `(filename, contents, media_type)`.
- [**Raw response access**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#accessing-raw-response-data-eg-headers): Access response headers and raw data with `.with_raw_response` and `.with_streaming_response`.
- [**Per-request configuration**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#retries): Override client options on a per-request basis with `.with_options()`.
- [**Configurable timeouts**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#timeouts): Fine-grained timeout control at the client or request level, including separate read/write/connect timeouts.
- [**Better error handling**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#handling-errors): Specific exception types for different HTTP status codes (`BadRequestError`, `AuthenticationError`, `RateLimitError`, etc.) with access to underlying response data.
- [**Manual pagination control**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#pagination): Granular page control with `has_next_page()`, `next_page_info()`, and `get_next_page()` methods.
- [**Response serialization**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#using-types): Pydantic models with built-in `.to_json()` and `.to_dict()` methods.
- [**Logging support**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#logging): Built-in logging via `REPLICATE_LOG` environment variable.
- [**Context manager support**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta#managing-http-resources): Proper resource management with context managers for both sync and async clients.

For more details about all these new features, see the [README](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta).

## Why rewrite?

The v2 Python SDK is generated dynamically from our public [OpenAPI schema](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/openapi). This allows us to automate client code generation and provide a Python API with method names, type hints, and documentation that is perfectly consistent with our HTTP API.

Now that most of the client code is generated dynamically, all changes to Replicates HTTP API are automatically supported by the Python SDK. This means whenever we add a new operation (like the [new search API](https://replicate.com/blog/new-search-api)) or improve our docs for an existing API (like [predictions.create()](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http#predictions.create)), the changes are automatically published in a new release of the Python SDK.

## Installation

To get started using the public beta pre-release, pip install it with the `--pre` flag:

```bash
pip install --pre replicate
```

## Usage

For basic usage, the new 2.x client works just like the old 1.x client.

As always, you can import the library and run models with just a few lines of code:

```bash
import replicate

model = "anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet"
prompt = "Write me a poem about SDKs"
output = replicate.run(model, input={"prompt": prompt})
print(output)
```

You can also stream output as the model is running:

```python
import replicate

claude = replicate.use("anthropic/claude-4.5-sonnet", streaming=True)

for event in claude(prompt="Write a haiku about streaming output."):
    print(str(event), end="")
```

Want to try it out but dont have Python at your disposal? Check out the [Google Colab notebook](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1FGlnCY1-TdYoyNsFg83L2lwFoWS5F7Xe?usp=sharing).

See [sdks.replicate.com/python](https://sdks.replicate.com/python/) for a complete summary of available methods.

## Migrating from v1 to v2

v2 is a complete rewrite of the Python SDK, so there are user-facing **breaking changes** you should be aware of if youre migrating an existing codebase from v1 to v2. Weve published a guide to simplify the migration process:

[**https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md**](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md)

We recommend feeding this guide to an agent like Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, Gemini CLI, or Cursor to help you automate the process of migrating your project from v1 to v2.

## Pinning to v1

v2 has lots of new bells and whistles, but you are not required to upgrade. If youre already using the v1 version and want to continue using it, pin the version number in your dependency file.

See [pinning](https://github.com/replicate/replicate-python-beta/blob/main/UPGRADING.md#pinning-to-the-legacy-v1-sdk) in the migration guide for details.

input.prompt: I want a more prominent notification when Claude prompts me for input. Can you create a Claude code hook that does something interesting when this input is needed?

tool_input.description: Check if audio playback is available
Check if audio playback is available

tool_input.prompt: What hook event is triggered when Claude needs user input or is waiting for the user to respond? List all available hook events.
What hook event is triggered when Claude needs user input or is waiting for the user to respond? List all available hook events.

tool_response.result:
# Hook Events in Claude Code

Based on the documentation, there is **no hook event specifically triggered when Claude is waiting for user input**. However, the `Notification` hook comes closestit runs when Claude sends notifications, including when "the prompt input has been idle for at least 60 seconds" with the message "Claude is waiting for your input."

## All Available Hook Events

Claude Code supports the following hook events:

1. **PreToolUse** - Runs after Claude creates tool parameters and before processing the tool call
2. **PostToolUse** - Runs immediately after a tool completes successfully
3. **Notification** - Runs when Claude sends notifications (permission requests or idle waiting messages)
4. **UserPromptSubmit** - Runs when the user submits a prompt, before Claude processes it
5. **Stop** - Runs when the main Claude Code agent finishes responding
6. **SubagentStop** - Runs when a Claude Code subagent (Task tool call) finishes responding
7. **PreCompact** - Runs before Claude Code executes a compact operation
8. **SessionStart** - Runs when Claude Code starts or resumes a session
9. **SessionEnd** - Runs when a Claude Code session ends

The `Notification` event is the primary mechanism for detecting idle waiting states or permission requirement scenarios.

tool_input.content:
#!/bin/bash

# Get the notification message from stdin
MESSAGE=$(cat)

# Only trigger for "waiting for input" notifications
if [[ "$MESSAGE" == *"waiting for your input"* ]] || [[ "$MESSAGE" == *"needs your input"* ]]; then
    # Play an alert sound (Glass is attention-grabbing but not annoying)
    afplay /System/Library/Sounds/Glass.aiff &

    # Display a prominent system notification with action button
    osascript -e "display notification \"$MESSAGE\" with title \" Claude Needs Your Input\" sound name \"Glass\""

    # Optional: Make terminal window bounce in dock (more prominent)
    osascript -e 'tell application "System Events" to set visible of process "Terminal" to true' 2>/dev/null || \
    osascript -e 'tell application "System Events" to set visible of process "iTerm2" to true' 2>/dev/null || \
    osascript -e 'tell application "System Events" to set visible of process "iTerm" to true' 2>/dev/null
fi

#!/bin/bash

# Get the notification message from stdin

tool_input.new_string:
#!/bin/bash

# Get the notification message from stdin
MESSAGE=$(cat)

# Only trigger for "waiting for input" notifications
if [[ "$MESSAGE" == *"waiting for your input"* ]] || [[ "$MESSAGE" == *"needs your input"* ]]; then
    # Play an alert sound three times for extra attention
    (afplay /System/Library/Sounds/Glass.aiff && sleep 0.2 && afplay /System/Library/Sounds/Glass.aiff && sleep 0.2 && afplay /System/Library/Sounds/Glass.aiff) &

    # Display a prominent dialog box that requires dismissal
    osascript <<EOF &
        display dialog " Claude is waiting for your input! " with title "Input Required" buttons {"OK"} default button "OK" with icon caution giving up after 10
EOF

    # Also show a system notification
    osascript -e "display notification \"$MESSAGE\" with title \" Claude Needs Your Input\" sound name \"Glass\""

    # Make terminal window bounce continuously in dock until dismissed
    osascript -e 'tell application "System Events"
        set activeApp to name of first application process whose frontmost is true
        if activeApp is not in {"Terminal", "iTerm2", "iTerm"} then
            set visible of process "Terminal" to true
        end if
    end tell' 2>/dev/null || \
    osascript -e 'tell application "System Events"
        set activeApp to name of first application process whose frontmost is true
        if activeApp is not in {"Terminal", "iTerm2", "iTerm"} then
            set visible of process "iTerm2" to true
        end if
    end tell' 2>/dev/null
fi
